sub_topic: The Mandelbrot set and its fractal properties
message_1: What is the smallest value of "c" in the formula Z(n+1) = Z(n)^2 + c such that the sequence Z(n) remains bounded? (Hint: This is related to the boundary of the Mandelbrot set.)
message_2:
The smallest value of "c" in the formula Z(n+1) = Z(n)^2 + c such that the sequence Z(n) remains bounded is c = -2.

This is related to the boundary of the Mandelbrot set, which is defined as the set of complex numbers c for which the sequence Z(n+1) = Z(n)^2 + c remains bounded when starting with Z(0) = 0. The boundary of the Mandelbrot set is known to lie between -2 and 2 along the real axis. When c = -2, the sequence remains bounded, as Z(n) oscillates between 0 and -2. For values of c less than -2, the sequence becomes unbounded.
